content.text: In the middle of the space below, draw a line, \(10\mathrm{cm}\) long, across the page and label it \(\mathbf{AB}\) . This line represents one side of the glass block
Draw a normal to this line at the centre of AB
Draw a line at \(30^{\circ}\) to the normal to represent an incident ray. This line should be at least \(6\mathrm{cm}\) long. Label this line \(\mathbf{EF}\)
A student finds that his completed results from the refraction experiment do not match the theory. The student carried out the experiment correctly and with reasonable care
Suggest a practical reason why the results could differ slightly from the results expected from the theory
[Total: 5]
The IGCSE class is carrying out refraction experiments using a rectangular glass block optical pins
Record room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) as shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.2

Calculate the temperature difference \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) between \(\theta_0\) and room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}} = (\theta_0 - \theta_{\mathrm{R}})\)
Calculate the temperature fall \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) of the hot water using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}} = (\theta_0 - \theta_1)\)
A student pours \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into a beaker. She records the temperature \(\theta_0\) of the water
She starts a stopclock and records the temperature \(\theta_{1}\) of the water at time \(t = 100 \text{s}\)

Calculate the temperature difference \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}}\) between \(\theta_{2}\) and room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}} = (\theta_{2} - \theta_{\mathrm{R}})\)
Calculate the temperature fall \(\theta_{\mathrm{W}}\) of the warm water using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{W}} = (\theta_{2} - \theta_{3})\)
The student empties the beaker. She pours \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water to the beaker, and stirs
She records the temperature \(\theta_{2}\) of the warm water
She starts the stopclock and records the temperature \(\theta_{3}\) of the water at time \(t = 100 \text{s}\)

The student suggests that the rate of temperature change is proportional to the difference between the starting temperature and room temperature. This can be expressed as \(\frac{\theta_{\mathrm{A}}}{\theta_{\mathrm{H}}} = \frac{\theta_{\mathrm{B}}}{\theta_{\mathrm{W}}}\)
State whether the results support this suggestion and justify your answer with reference to the results
statement
justification
If this experiment were to be repeated in order to check results, it would be important to control the conditions
Suggest two such conditions that should be controlled
[Total: 8]
An IGCSE class is investigating the rate of cooling of water
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 2.1
A student measures the current at positions 1, 2 and 3 in the circuit. Record the current at each position as shown on the ammeters in Fig. 3.3
Calculate the total current \(I_{\mathrm{C}}\) in the combination of lamps using the equation \(I_{\mathrm{C}} = I_{2} + I_{3}\)
Theory indicates that \(I_{1} = I_{\mathrm{C}}\). Suggest why a student may find the two values to be different in this experiment
The student decides to investigate the effect of changing the current \(I_{1}\), using a variable resistor (rheostat)
In the space below, copy the diagram shown in Fig. 3.1, but with the addition of a variable resistor connected at a suitable position for the investigation
A student sets up the circuit as shown in Fig. 3.1. Neither of the two lamps in series glows. He suspects that one of the lamps is faulty
Suggest how the apparatus may be used to find out which lamp is faulty
The IGCSE class is investigating current and potential difference using identical lamps circuit
The circuit is shown in Fig. 3.1
Calculate the value of \(uv\) for each set of readings and enter the values in the table
Complete the column headings in the table by inserting the units for \(uv\) and \(d\)
Complete the labelling of the axes below, and plot the graph using data from the You do not need to begin the axes at the origin (0,0)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
State a value for the focal length \(f\) of the lens, giving your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
[Total: 10]
The gradient of the graph is numerically equal to the focal length of the lens
The IGCSE class is determining the focal length of a lens
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 4.1
A student places a lens at a distance \(u = 30.0 \text{cm}\) from an illuminated object. She moves the screen until a sharply focused image of the object is seen on the screen
She measures the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen. She calculates \(d\), using the equation \(d = u + v\)
She repeats the procedure using a range of values of \(u\). The values of \(u\), \(v\) and \(d\) are shown in Table 4.1
On Fig. 5.1, measure the length \(l\) of the pendulum
The diagram is drawn \(1 / 5^{\text{th}}\) actual size
Calculate the actual length \(L\) of the pendulum
A student places a metre rule on the bench so that the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark is vertically
the centre of the pendulum bob. Describe how you would judge that the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark vertically below the centre of the pendulum bob. You may draw a diagram
Calculate the period \(T\) of the pendulum for each value of \(d\). Enter the values in the table. The period \(T\) is the time taken for one complete swing of the pendulum.
Complete the column headings in the table
The student pulls the pendulum bob to one side until it is vertically above the \(52.0 \text{cm}\) mark on the rule. He has moved the pendulum bob a horizontal distance \(d = 2.0 \text{cm}\)

He releases the pendulum bob, then measures the time \(t\) taken for 12 complete swings of the pendulum. He repeats the procedure using a range of \(d\) values. The values of \(d\) and \(t\) are shown in Table 5.1
Using the evidence in the table, describe the effect on the period \(T\) of increasing the distance \(d\). Justify your answer by reference to your results
description
justification
Suggest why the student measures the time taken for twelve swings of the pendulum rather than for one swing
[Total: 10]
The IGCSE class is investigating a pendulum
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 5.1
